thread.section_title: Nikon SLR Lens Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: Replacing [maybe and hopefully] the 28-300VR2 with...:
thread.title_full: Replacing [maybe and hopefully] the 28-300VR2 with...: Nikon SLR Lens Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: Giovanni_1968
posts.title: Replacing [maybe and hopefully] the 28-300VR2 with...:
posts.text:
Long story (hopefully) short, never liked the 28-300 too much, never saw much use since I like primes for my hobby which, mainly, is candid portraits where the 60/2.8G (I have an old 50/1.4D which doesn't do well with the D800) and 85/1.8G do almost all I like but a zoom comes handy in everyday photography where I always have in the bag also the 60 or the 85 (sometimes the 150/2.8 too) and where the 28mm end comes handy when the occasion arises or when the primes are too tight so my idea was either to give the zoom away and to get the 20/1.8G which is on my bucket list for winter seascapes/landscapes (the island where I live gives plenty inspiration for seascapes) or to get a shorter range but more luminous zoom to give me the ability to both shoot some candid portrait and some landscape with the extra 4mm on the wide end until I can fund a proper wide angle prime.
I can't afford a 24-70/2.8 and there isn't much alternative besides the Sigma 24-105Art/4 whose reviews are kinda mixed, I know it being very sharp so it would work as a wide angle substitute in the meantime but dunno if f4 would allow enough blur (and I can try with the 85 shot at f4 to find out) and about the blur quality most of all, any hint or suggestion for some different lens should I sell the 28-300?
Grazie
-- hide signature -- Giovanni - 70% GAS affected
http://www.flickr.com/photos/giovanniaprea/
Nikon D800 - Nikon D2Xs - Fuji X-Pro1 - Fuji S5Pro - Panasonic DMC-L1 - Nikon F - Nikon F3

thread.section_title: Nikon SLR Lens Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: Replacing [maybe and hopefully] the 28-300VR2 with...:
thread.title_full: Replacing [maybe and hopefully] the 28-300VR2 with...: Nikon SLR Lens Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: ormdig
posts.text:
Quote: :
Quote: :
HI Giovanni, what is your price range? Can you swing a used 24-70g? I have used one (I bought new) with wonderful results for 5 years on my D800. It is much faster and more accurate focusing than the 3rd party lenses including the Sigma 24-105. I shoot with a friend who uses a 24-105 on a Canon and it is on par with your 28-300 in focusing and image quality (in the same focal length).
I have no doubt the 24-70, whichever any review, is better than both my 28-300 and the 24-105 but it would be out of my range, I am fine with adding a couple hundred bucks on top of what I would make out of my lens which is where I would get with the Sigma 24-105 but wouldn't go any further.
Oh come on, I understand third party lenses could face trouble but can't believe quality being on par with the 28-300!
Well, I was comparing the 28-300 at it's strongest focal lengths vs the entire range of the Sigma. I don't think I am too far off. It's not a significant improvement any way you look at it. I just looked at B&H trying to find used prices and saw that there is a new 24-105 Art lens. I don't know anything about that. I am speaking of the older lens. I apologize if I was mistaken. Most of the Art series are fairly well received.
I didn't quite get whether you are looking for the wide or long end. I would suggest the Nikkor 105 f/1.4 if you are looking at the longer end as it is fabulous for candid portrait work. I find myself using it for landscape work a lot. Had to redefine what I thought of as landscape but boy can it give you some beautifully different perspectives,
If I could afford the 105/1.4 we wouldn't be here...
I couldn't afford it but after seeing some of the image people were posting I got pretty creative with my budget. Well worth it,
-- hide signature -- Pete
Grazie Pete

thread.section_title: Nikon SLR Lens Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: Yongnuo 50/1.8 is an OK lens:
thread.title_full: Yongnuo 50/1.8 is an OK lens: Nikon SLR Lens Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: Lightpath48
posts.title: Yongnuo 50/1.8 is an OK lens:
posts.text:
Quote: :
I find using the LCD screen gives better focus. Part of the reason is you can magnify for better focusing accuracy.
Using LV and magnifying the image for MF is great. Before trying that, I had no idea how fast this lens goes through the distances. No wonder there are minor AF errors. These were all manually focused using the technique in your post. I think they match, or exceed the image quality from my former Nikon 50mm f/1.8 D.

thread.section_title: Nikon SLR Lens Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: Need to replace Tamron 17-50 2.8 since Tamron won't repair it - suggestions? (D7200):
thread.title_full: Need to replace Tamron 17-50 2.8 since Tamron won't repair it - suggestions? (D7200): Nikon SLR Lens Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: StillLearning
posts.text:
Quote: :
Hi guys,
Currently have the Tamron 17-50 2.8 non-VC. Despite Tamron's own website saying they service this lens, upon sending it in I get an email stating it's no longer repairable - discontinued. I sent it in for a calibration, since the edges were starting to have severe blurriness.
So setting my frustrations aside with that fiasco, can anyone recommend a replacement? I need this range for an upcoming trip. Is the Sigma 17-50 2.8 OS the best bang for the buck currently? I want something that will look sharp with the D7200's sensor.
I hear the Sigma 18-35 1.8 is nice, but I don't want to shell out $800. For me, the 17-50 is typically a daytime lens, so sharpness is my main concern.
What can you guys recommend? This will compliment a Tokina 11-16, 2 primes, and a 55-300VR.
Thanks!
Have you considered the Sigma 17-70C 2.8-4? I've had mine going on 4 years. Works with the USB dock. Been waiting for Sigma to upgrade their 17-50 but no rumors so far. Have used it with my D7100 and D7200.

thread.section_title: Nikon SLR Lens Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: Need to replace Tamron 17-50 2.8 since Tamron won't repair it - suggestions? (D7200):
thread.title_full: Need to replace Tamron 17-50 2.8 since Tamron won't repair it - suggestions? (D7200): Nikon SLR Lens Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: André BARELIER
posts.title: Need to replace Tamron 17-50 2.8 since Tamron won't repair it - suggestions? (D7200):
posts.text:
Another vote for the 17-50mm F2.8 EX DC OS HSM.
Well built, can take some rain too (though of course do not try this yourself etc) good colours, tonality and acuity, excellent at 50mm and decent fast AF, not 'blistering' FF top lens fast or slow kit lens 'just sort of fast' but 'quite fast.'
Mine lives in my D5300 as a 24mm, 35mm and 50mm three in one prime.
Only thing not good = MF, focus ring as bad as a kit lens and not best bokeh but this is a fast AF, get any shot in any condition kind of lens that is excellent for 95% of any type of application.
Had mine about two years and used it a lot, very long and hard usage. Been rained on, dropped, taken knocks and bumps and still good as new.
A real DX winner in my books and most of the top reviewers rate it as good as the Nikon 17-5mmm F2.8 except slightly slower AF and slightly lesser build, but optically as good.
Winner winner chicken dinner, especially if you're on a budget the value for money especially with Sigmas free extended warranty is great.
IQ difference to kit lens 18-55mm VR II very noticeable jump IME.
Good for travel, street, portraits, reportage, walkaround etc.
Not so great for landscape, just not sharp enough all over frame at WA really for that, acceptable, but not for if Landscape is your main type of photography obviously.

thread.section_title: Nikon SLR Lens Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: Need to replace Tamron 17-50 2.8 since Tamron won't repair it - suggestions? (D7200):
thread.title_full: Need to replace Tamron 17-50 2.8 since Tamron won't repair it - suggestions? (D7200): Nikon SLR Lens Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: 1llusive
posts.text:
If you're looking in the same focal range, the Sigma 18-50 is the closest to what you have. The 17-70 will be a downgrade in IQ.
However, the Sigma 18-50 doesn't work well on our cameras.
I would recommend the Nikon 16-80. It will match the Tamron the closest and it should work properly on your D7200 - the reports I've seen show it is the 7100 and older that can't compensate for the focus shift of the 16-80.
Look on eBay for new, but separated-from-the-kit lenses. Don't pay retail. Or, buy the D7500 kit and get the lens for even less, about $600 USD.

thread.section_title: Open Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: Selling at Art Fairs?:
thread.title_full: Selling at Art Fairs?: Open Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: peter826
posts.title: Selling at Art Fairs?:
posts.text:
Anyone here selling photos at art fairs? I've been considering this, but would be curious to hear other's stories about their experiences.
My background: was taking a few photos here and there while traveling, and have gradually gotten more interested in photography. I have hung framed prints in a few coffee shops and at the library once, and they have sold quite well. However, my price point is quite low -- maybe $40 for a framed 8x10. I have tried to keep prices down to a point where people don't have to stop and think too hard about buying something -- they see something they like and will grab it. I'm not well known and I don't think people would pay a premium for my work.
At an Art Fair, the profit margin for selling just a print with mat in a bag would be much higher. However, setting up would require buying a tent, setting up a way to take payment online, getting fixtures to house prints, etc. Seems like a very large investment and could take a lot of time on weekends (less time to shoot!) Plus I have a small car, might even have to rent a vehicle to haul everything?
I'd like to hear your experiences, if you have anything to share.

thread.section_title: Open Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: What got you into photography?:
thread.title_full: What got you into photography?: Open Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: minababe
posts.title: What got you into photography?:
posts.text:
As a kid, I would always browse the art section of the library and come across these photo books, especially anthologies from Life Magazine. I also liked the feel of using a camera, even if it was a dinky one.
My first real camera was a Pentax K1000 when I went to art school. I still was using it right up until the time I went digital in 2005.
There are several things that keep me going. One of them is to try out cameras. Another is to improve my artistic and technical ability. A third reason is inspiration. A last reason is that it's in my DNA to keep taking photographs. I stopped drawing but I've never been able to stop taking pictures, even those years when I've lost interest.

posts.author: MolecularMan
posts.title: Best place for cheap 8x10 prints?:
posts.text:
I had the idea to do free portraits for a local nursing facility I work for.
The administration wants to do a Christmas theme and give out the prints during Christmas.
I'm not sure where to go for 8x10 prints. They all seem to be around 1.50-3+ bucks. I see this place qprints.com offers 70 cent prints, which is like half the cost of other places I've found.
Any thoughts? Places that are cheap and reputable?
Thanks!

posts.author: MaxCh
posts.text:
Quote: :
No Costco around, and seems comparable to Sam's in price.
This qprints place supposedly does them for 70 cents and offers color correction for 20 cents.. so 90 cents a piece for an 8x10. That seems too good to be true. They say they are a "Division of Fromex Photo & ProLabPrints.com"
I would strongly suggest NOT to use Costco. I just tried to print some beautiful photos taken with Canon 5D mark 4 and various L lenses. The colors did not come right. I tried again at a different center and still got bad prints (not too bad but certainly not as good as in the original images).

thread.section_title: Pentax SLR Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: Just bought a K1....:
thread.title_full: Just bought a K1....: Pentax SLR Talk Forum: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: klavrack
posts.text:
Pentax forums has a user-review database of all current and legacy lenses--just the ticket to answer your question. Following their guide, I got a FA20-35/4 that made a nice lightweight landscape lens for my K-1. For macro on the K-1, it's hard to beat the Vivitar/Kiron 105mm at any price. I also got a FA*300/4.5 on their recommendation.
Other than the macro, though, I'll be putting it all on Ebay in a month...lovely combo, but we're trying to go in a much more lightweight direction.
One other note--yes, the A50/1.2 is great, but some versions of the 50mm 1.4 and 1.7 are nearly as good for a whole lot less money.
Mr Quote: :
Now I need lenses. What are the "sleeper" legacy lenses in the K-Mount system? I am more interested in auto aperture lenses, so I guess that would be the A series lenses.
Thanks

thread.section_title: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: Not quite as good? Nikon D850 versus Nikon D5 subject tracking:
thread.title_full: Not quite as good? Nikon D850 versus Nikon D5 subject tracking: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: dash2k8
posts.text: Having read a few "D850's AF tracking is not as good as D5" articles here and elsewhere on the net, I think what's really important is: is the D850's tracking "good enough"? If it is... who cares if it's not as accurate as D5 aside from calling out Nikon for false advertisement?

thread.section_title: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: Not quite as good? Nikon D850 versus Nikon D5 subject tracking:
thread.title_full: Not quite as good? Nikon D850 versus Nikon D5 subject tracking: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: Zdman
posts.text: 3D tracking is where Nikon has a perceived advantage at the moment. Dpreview tend to be Nikon fans so as I already predicted some time ago expect to be told constantly how important 3D tracking is. That's the first question answered.

thread.section_title: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: Not quite as good? Nikon D850 versus Nikon D5 subject tracking:
thread.title_full: Not quite as good? Nikon D850 versus Nikon D5 subject tracking: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: Zdman
posts.text: Oh I agree but Dpreview is trying to imply the opposite and I'm saying without a standardised test they're effectively living in a glass house and throwing stones.

thread.section_title: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: Not quite as good? Nikon D850 versus Nikon D5 subject tracking:
thread.title_full: Not quite as good? Nikon D850 versus Nikon D5 subject tracking: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: Cthulion
posts.text: Because none of the things you've mentioned track the subjects, in a similar way that if I take a hard drive out of 1 pc and install it in another it'll perform exactly the same. Things you didn't mention that could actually influence the results of this test are the shutter mechanism and how much voltage gets through to the physical autofocus drive. I suspect the gap in the test would be smaller if the d850 had it's battery grip.

posts.author: Vignes
posts.text: more important test would D850 vs D500 on AF tracking since the D850 is pitched as a do all (D810, D500, D5) camera. I like Matt G type of testing (irregular light, subject moving side to side, up and down while moving towards the camera). This will help Nikon users purchase decision. Canon user is a Canon user and most of them are tied to the lens than the camera itself.

thread.section_title: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: The Nikon D850 could be the only DSLR you’ll ever need:
thread.title_full: The Nikon D850 could be the only DSLR you’ll ever need: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: vaughanB
posts.text:
Of course the cameras you mention are are great cameras and produce excellent output for pro work, what I am saying is that as somebody that earns my living from taking photographs, I can buy a rugged, weather sealed pro body camera like a barely used D300s for £329.00 and it does what I need it to do, if I spent 10 times that amount on a D850 it wouldn't earn me another penny, the D300s is perfectly good enough and has all the features I need, this was not the case years ago when one had to spend as much as one could afford, constantly trying to reach a higher image quality and performance level as cameras were never quite good enough.
If I had plenty of spare cash to waste, sure I would enjoy owning a D850, but I don't need one enough spend that kind of money when older barely used pro bodies that are perfectly adequate are available, I know my colleagues think the same way, years ago I would have bought a new D300s but now don't need state of the art any more, oder cams suffice

posts.author: Samuel C
posts.text:
Brown, I think he's saying that it appears you're implying that since others are stating opinions then you think your statements must, therefore, be fact. Just my guess.
No, I didn't say what someone should do. I said that if you shoot raw for good reasons then a JPEG could never be good enough to sway you. If you shoot raw because you want to post process, then you want the kind of control a JPEG encoding algorithm will never give you. If you're ambivalent about the format then maybe a super high res image in JPEG would eliminate your previous concerns. BUT, raw will always have more data than JPEG and the DR advantage of modern sensors is almost entirely erased by JPEG encoding.

thread.section_title: Astrophotography Talk Forum Forum: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: How to merge Milky Way images???:
thread.title_full: How to merge Milky Way images???: Astrophotography Talk Forum Forum: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: twomonger
posts.text:
I use PaintShop due to my dislike for subscription software, but this should be easily replicated in PhotoShop.
Post your images so I can get an idea of how hard it is.
IMO, merging ultimately boils down to two problems:
1. Selection.
2. Merging tracked areas (only applicable if tracking was used).
How hard it is to solve these problems depends on what you took a picture of. Also tracking.
Untracked with simple rocks/mountains is a piece of cake. Just use a smart selection tool to grab the foreground from your foreground exposure (since the simple edges are easily recognized by the software) and then copy and paste. Done.
Tracking makes it a little harder, especially since the rotation of the tracked exposure with respect to the RA axis makes it non-trivial to unrotate your sky exposure. I usually cut a corner here. I copy the earth exposure to the sky one as a new layer and then use the clone tool by copying over the rocks/mountains to the blurred areas from the sky exposure so there's no blurred foregrounds. Alternatively you can clone stars to fill in the blurred areas.
There's an even easier method, which is to overlay your foreground such that it completely blocks any blurring due to tracking (typically by moving the foreground up from where it originally was). To me, this is going too far away from reality, since the ground is "higher" than in life. Others go even further in their distorting reality, like pasting sky exposures taken at different times of year or even different locations! It is incredibly obvious once you recognize it. Very common trick by Instagram "photographers."
With any type of trees, selection is much less trivial. There are two methods that I have tried that work. One is first aggressively stretching the foreground exposure to create a significant difference in brightness between the foreground and sky. Then use a brightness based selection method to select the foreground. Save this selection and then revert to the unstreched foreground exposure and reload it to grab the foreground. Copy and paste.
Alternatively, you can use masks to achieve the same thing. A bit more complicated, but it works on the same underlying principle of using brightness/intensity of various colors to differentiate land and sky. This youtube tutorial does a good job of explaining... its a bit tedious to write out. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H6I9Q-b2pQc&t=537s
Again, if you use a tracker, merging with trees is even more of a pain. You'll have to find what works for you when it comes to filling in the blurred spaces. Careful use of the clone tool has been my preference, but then again I have not had any shots that I really feel happy with doing serious work on.
Finally, the relative brightness/white balance of sky and foreground is your artistic choice. But those are all trivial to adjust once you've figured out the critical problem of selection and merging.
If you have examples, I can show you my workflow.
Edit: Panoramas are an even harder problem that I am currently unable to solve. It seems like everyone in this forum recommends a panorama for astrophotography because of the superior light gathering ability... but the inconsistent and irreproducible distortion (infuriating) introduced by the generation of separate panoramas for foreground and sky have made it impossible for me to merge the two successfully!
(Note: Mosaic mode gets rid of the stupid distortion introduced by panorama software)
And not to mention the whole other can of worms introduced by stitching tracked sky exposures that happen to contain land... since the sky moves but land does not. It seems to drive most panorama software that i've used (hugin, microsoft ICE), nuts!

posts.author: Sdaniella
posts.text:
Sony Cybershot DSC-R1 - Shot mostly JPEGs @ ISO 160
before shooting mostly JPEGs on Canon EOS 5DMk II @ ISO 800
for years!
in those days, pp RAW was not so enjoyable on a Windows Desktop pc 24" (1920x1200) only in 2017, this year
now revisiting exploring RAW CR2 on my Canon 5D2 @ ISO 100/160
and RAW SR2 on my SONY R1 @ ISO 160
explore to pp for DR
*finally* enjoying pp RAW* with free Android LR Mobile and free Android Snapseed, which are so easy to use on my Galaxy Tab S 10.5" (2560x1600 AMOLED)!!!
bringing new life to both my older cameras, and taking advantages of RAW pp over JPEG pp
both use CFI/II cards, but recently got a micro-SD/SD-to-CFII adapter, and 128GB micro-SD/SD UHS-I memory cards, which provide (hundreds!!!) plenty of RAW+JPEG pics on either camera! *yay*
practiced pp RAW initially with my budget Canon Powershot SX50HS superzoom
*
Canon CR2 converted to DNG with free Android RAW2DNG
SONY SR2 converted to 16-bit TIFF with free Android DCRaw
both apps on GooglePlay

posts.author: fletchhollywood
posts.text: I was filming an interview last week with the NX1. I started the recording at 1920 and 24 fps. Roughly eleven minutes in, I looked over and saw the NX1 had stopped and was in a sub-routine, wanting me to select the picture wizard settings. I turned the camera off and on and restarted. It ran 29 seconds and did the same thing. I restarted and it ran for 9:37, and did the same thing. I restarted and it ran 3:55. Then it ran for 29:59:1, when it stopped as it should. Then I restarted and it ran to the end. I love the camera. The only thing I can think it did was that I was in the Samsung section of a Best Buy the day before and asked him to help me set up the NFC. The camera started the process but didn't finish. So I kept it on and left the store for it to finish. I don't know if it ever did finish, so I finally shut it off. That was all the day before.

posts.author: Claudio NC
posts.text:
Not true that the 2 shots of Real World Dynamic Range are taken at the same time, obviously. "Same time" mean same time, exactly (max within fractions of seconds), but here are taken at different times. May be only seconds, but this small difference have a little impact, may be real little only, on some aspects and details, but they are present and visible.
The most obvious aspect that shows the different times between the 2 shots is in the car traffic, but there are also different color intensity in some parts of cloud strips (in the Samsung appear more intensely orange, while in the Nikon, no, they are more prone to the brown gray).
On the left, significant differences are visible in the red part of vertical SkyeBelltown.com panels, less noise-blurred and more saturated with Samsung.
This probably is a real camera rendition difference.
In any case this is not a well done comparison.
CONTINUES ...

thread.title_full: Samsung NX1 Review: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: Redirector
posts.text: Nikon User here, NPS. After seeing the NX1 in a seminar, I came away impressed and interested. At present 80% of my work is stills, 20% video, but I can see the advantages of 4k and the Samsung ease-of-use touch screens and AF improvements -- the NX1 delivers quality without a huge learning curve. With a few workflow modifications, this would be a viable addition to a Nikon professional photographer's kit if they wanted to add a 4K option, even to the point of incorporating Nikon lenses via adapter (manual, for now). But I would still grab the 16-50mm S lens to take advantage of all the AF and Samsung integration for video. Even the Android apps look helpful. All this should be value-add for clients needing video, and expand my capabilities, and the $2800 kit package seems a value, relatively speaking. Those who have shopped the other options how do you compare this price-value-capability package vs other options Sony Panasonic Olympus etc? Thank you

posts.author: Claudio NC
posts.text:
Who tells me that the difference in some cloud saturation is produced by these 2 cameras, or post production, instead of the sun position and/or the clouds themselves interacting between them? When I do test like these, to evaluate the color rendering and the dynamic range between 2, 3 or 4 cameras, these must take exactly at the same time, cameras mounted as much as possible nearby one to the other and of course with remote control and/or 2 or more second self delay.
The evaluation of the proper exposures times, eventually different between the cameras, in order to have the exposure levels as similar as possible, must have done before begin the real comparison test.
Then you are free to shoot, at the same time, a lot of exposure bracketings.
It is not a good operative technique to do the opposite, shotting at the same time with the same diaphragms-times and later compare different exposures, taken in different moments, to compensate different cameras renditions.

thread.section_title: Reviews and previews: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: Samsung NX1
thread.title_full: Samsung NX1 Review: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: matander
posts.text:
The NX1 is definitely worth gold! Before and even more after FW 1.30 update.
I used it this weekend with FW1.30 and 18-55 ki tlens at a running event in Gothenburg with very high hit rate. Firmware 1.30 radically improves lowlight AF performance and the new Zone AF with together with Continuous AF or Active AF works great for subject tracking. Connectivity, cropability, ISO performance is icing on the cake. I cannot understand people saying ISO performance of NX1 is bad,especially comparing it to 7D II.
Some lens options are still missing, especially long tele (fixed and zooms) but the lenses that are available is mostly better than the competition. The video features and performance outshines the competition by a margin, subject tracking is much better than GH4 (dont know if 7d II does focus tracking in video or live view AF).
FW 1.30 boosted the Video capability further vith fullHD 120 fps (4x SloMo) and improved rollingshutter for 4k video.
Is Diamond available?
/Mats

posts.author: HowaboutRAW
posts.text:
grammieb: Right the D810 is a better high ISO camera than the NX1, but that's not a camera you've brought up. The D750 is also a better high ISO camera. Both Nikons are a good bit better than the Canon 5DIII or the 5DS. And the 5DS has plenty of noise at ISO 3200.
The optically better lenses from Samsung are better than Nikon's best.

posts.author: tecnoworld
posts.text: Grammie, we are obviously looking at different pictures ;-) in the dpr studio comparison tool, as in the link I posted some msg above, it is very clear that a 6d, which is already better than 5diii, is really close to nx1 at iso 3200, if both are scaled down to 20mp. This is a great great achievement from a sensor which is twice as smaller. Besides the nx1 has shooting performance that can be matched (with fw 1.4) or surpassed (with prev fw) only by the three times as expensive, twice as heavy (and big) and half resolution 1dx :-D

thread.section_title: Reviews and previews: Digital Photography Review
thread.title: Samsung NX1
thread.title_full: Samsung NX1 Review: Digital Photography Review

posts.author: QuarryCat
posts.text:
the camera is not worth gold.
IF I compare withe GH4, X-T1 and a Eos 7D2, I would never buy a Samsung NX1.
The lenses are missing.
The AF is only good and accurate in good light.
The High-ISO Performance is bad.
The ergonomics are bad for me - much worse and less logical the GH4.
The performance is not that much better then the GH4 - nor will you get sharp pictures with 15 p/s on moving subjects.
For my feeling - after trying the NX1 for 3 weeks - it is pushed here, like in many magazines - for what reason ever. It is good that we all have with Samsung even more range on cameras, to push the sleeping Canon, Nikon, Pentax, Leica.
So welcome, but I will not buy it, because it can't deliver the pictures that I need.
Samsung will need a 4,0/10-24 mm OIS and much more lenses - maybe with the 2,8/300 mm and extender - I will change my mind with a NX2.

You two do what you do best, bragging about what you own & making obvious & unsuccessful attempts to discredit others while patting yourselves on the back. I am going out to shoot & enjoy my cameras. posts.author: HowaboutRAW
posts.text:
grammieb14: So, I extracted the ISO 3200 raws I shot with a 5DIII, NX1, and 5DSR–used ACR 9.1.
To my eye the 5DIII is tiny bit noisier than the NX1 at ISO 3200, but it’s close.
Now of more interest, and Samsung should pay attention, the 5DSR is better than both the NX1 and 5DIII at ISO 3200. Yes, I made sure to look at images with the same pixel density displayed on my monitor and I checked the noise in deep shadows–all of the tests were shot in very similar light.
